Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me at 248-860-4532
with any questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to
someone immediately, please contact the area manager at 734-395-0920.
Sincerely,
Deborah Will, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.12308 Application submission.
Section (1) An agency shall act on a completed and signed application.
Description
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency did not act on a signed foster parent application.
Investigation The Complainant, also Perspective Foster Parent (PFP) filed an
online complaint and did not provide a phone number. Via email I
notified her I was assigned to investigate her complaint and did
not receive a response.
On 2/23/2023, I notified the Chief Administrator via email of the
allegation filed against the agency. I held a conference call with
Licensing Supervisors 1 and 2, and Licensing Worker 1 on
2/23/2023. I requested documentation and a summary of the
actions taken on PFP’s foster home application by the agency.
Documents Reviewed
Foster Home application DCWL-3389 signed and dated by
applicant on 4/2/2022
Licensing Record Clearance DCWL-1326 (not dated by applicant)
Foster Home Contact Sheets
On 2/27/2023 Licensing Supervisor 2 provided the following
chronological summary of events:
2

On 11/12/2021, the agency received a licensing referral for PFP
as she had children placed in her home and was considered a
fictive kin placement. From January – April 2022, PFP completed
orientation, GROW trainings and background/fingerprinting.
PFP completed and signed a foster home application on 4/2/2022.
Licensing Worker 1 was assigned on 4/19/22. Enrollment
documents were completed and sent to DCWL in May 2022. In
June 2022, the first initial home assessment was completed where
PFP was informed that financial and Administrative Review Team
(ART) documents were needed due to her criminal history.
Further she was informed her fingerprints had to be redone due to
her failing to sign the required document.
From July – September 2022, contact with PFP was sporadic as
she reported to the licensing worker that she was no longer able
to care for the children in her home due to finances. PFP also
was unable to provide valid criminal history information which
made the ART difficult to complete.
In September 2022, PFP reported to the licensing worker that she
had redone her fingerprints. At that time, the licensing worker
informed her another home assessment and updated financial
information were needed due to the time that had passed and the
composition of the household changing. In October 2022, PFP
allowed Licensing Worker 1 to complete a second home
assessment. Again, PFP was informed of all documentation that
would be needed. Although the process was explained to her,
PFP became upset whenever new or additional documents were
requested. Licensing Worker 1 continued efforts to contact PFP,
but she was uncooperative through December 2022. In early
2023, she contacted Licensing Worker 1 stating she had gotten
“lazy” which is why she had not submitted documents. PFP was
reminded that additional/new documentation would need to be
submitted. At that point, she became upset and belligerent toward
Licensing Worker 1 and Licensing Supervisor 2.
In early February 2022, a meeting was suggested with foster care,
licensing and PFP. However, PFP refused indicating she would
not speak with licensing and was going to file a complaint.
To date PFP still has not provided proof of income or that her rent
is current. Further, she reported she will never pay the entire
amount of what is due on her rent, utilities and phone bill which is
causing her bills to increase and a risk of shut offs.
3

Licensing Supervisor 2 indicated that the agency is still interested
in continuing efforts to license PFP. However, her cooperation in
submitting proof of her income, rent and utilities payments is
essential to completing the process.
Analysis Documentation provided by the agency shows they acted on
PFP’s completed and signed application.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
February 28, 2023
______________________________________
Deborah Will Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
March 8, 2023
